title: How To Punish Toxic League Of Legends Players
body: So I was thinking that riot should make a feature that if a player gets reported for toxicity at least by 3 players they are gonna review the chatlogs and stuff and how the players was being toxic, and if the it is confirmed that the player is toxic, riot would reward them with less ip per win and have a ribbon that indicates that they are a toxic player (only for a certain amount of time) and if they still continue to be toxic their punishment duration is extended and they would be earning less ip etc. It does not have to ip but they can also make it where if the player is toxic, the player would be unable to purchase things in the shop that non-toxic players are able to purchase. What do you guys think?

replies.body:
Most of these are pretty good ideas actually. In fact, **Riot** already had a similar system to your "player reviewed reports" idea. They called it the [Tribunal](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/The_Tribunal).

The Tribunal is essentially a report system where players act as a jury and vote on punishments. **Riot** took down the old tribunal a while back, but now they've started work on the [updated tribunal](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/mEIlagLk-when-is-the-tribunal-coming-back?comment=0006).

The Tribunal system sucked ass, giving players the ability to spam whatever they want just to get the rewards they 'earned' was the dumbest idea since the dynamic queue changes.

The rewards you got, if you can even call it that, was not enough to justify spending the right amount of time per case to actually review the chat correctly and make an informed decision, therefore players would just spam whatever they wanted, get through their 20 cases in 20 minutes and get the same IP you would if you had just played some games, but with less stress than actually playing.

Unless you get the right people who actually care and want to make this game better, regardless of pay or rewards, you may actually get somewhere, too bad there are just too many who want nothing more than to punish everyone since it makes them fell like a big man.

I thought the tribunal was actually really cool. Especially when they released the [Justice Review](http://riot-web-static.s3.amazonaws.com/images/news/September_2012/2012_09_12_tribunal/justicereview.jpg) cards. You could see how many players you helped ban, toxic days prevented... etc.

I'd imagine most of the points you brought up, are a large reason why the Tribunal was taken down for a rework though.

hopefully the will update it soon because i'm sick of toxic players being toxic and getting away with it and they end up doing it all over again. I don't care if they are toxic to me because I can handle it, I just want the community to be close to a toxic-free community :P

I'm not sure what image you have of the current system, but the[ Instant Feedback](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/207489286-Instant-Feedback-System-FAQ-) system we have now is working really well. I'm not saying it is absolutely perfect, but it definitely deserves far more credit than it's given.

I see people coming to the forums all the time asking how to reform. I see people being banned on here frequently as well. I talk with Player Support specialists who also tell me the same thing. Instant Feedback is banning toxic players as we speak.

> _But wait, if Instant Feedback is working so well, why do I still see toxic players in the community?_
> 
> + A lot of the toxicity you see in-game is actually from good players. These people are usually positive, but every now and then they'll have an off-day. The average League player is like this.
> 
>  Your average League player might go toxic and receive a chat restriction, but then they won't become toxic for the next 6 months. But since there are so many of them it's actually fairly likely you'll run into a few during a week of play. **Riot** says these people account for [77%](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nbYQ0AVVBGU&feature=youtu.be&t=4m34s) of all toxicity in League (which is massive).
> 
> + The other reason is that toxic players still exist in League. The system is not perfect.
> 
>  One of the system's faults is it gives people time to reform. This is a good feature for most players, but really toxic players are given the benefit of the doubt by the system, when really they should be perma-banned instantly.
> 
> + [Negativity Bias](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negativity_bias) also plays a big role in this. Essentially, people tend to remember negative events more than positive ones.
> 
>  You can actually track how this affects you in your games. **Seras** has a great exercise for that [here](http://boards.oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behaviour/xvZeJNIU-riot-please-try-to-fix-your-community?comment=000100000000).

I absolutely understand where you're coming from. Let me be clear, I'm not saying _"toxicity doesn't exist in League"_, it's definitely there and still far too prominent. We need to put pressure on **Riot** to fix this.

It saddens me though when players think **Riot** doesn't care/does nothing. They really are trying! But this is a massive issue which might never actually be completely solved.

Thanks for reading such a long post :D

Yeh but a bot cannot differentiate between someone typing no bad words and being a cunt vs. someone who types all bad words, but doesn't actually say anything bad to anyone in particular.

I am for having a system that punishes those who deserve the punishment, but Riot either needs to recruit paid staff to do so, or recruit players who actually give a toss and get them to do it for free.

By implementing any other system, especially that of the old Tribunal system, you are essentially giving players the power to spam punish without actually reading the content and making the correct informed decision since the reward they were giving was not worth the time it took to do it properly, this meant players either spammed anything or didn't do it at all and those who did do it right? Well since there were so little of us we couldn't keep up with the system by doing it the right way, so it was inevitably removed and has yet to be replaced.
